content:
, 2014
												World of Guns: Gun Disassembly. A very simple game for those who love firearms or want to know more about firearms.This is not really a game where you have fun compared to shooters or simulators or simulators that are made for the lolz.This game is educational or an easy 3D source material for those who make replicas, fix guns etc.The game starts well. It tells you how the game works and what you can do in a very straightforward manner.The rules are simple. You unlock a model, play the game modes, unlock achievements and receive xp to unlock the next model.The game modes are: field strip, disassembly, assembly, operation, game, supergame and hardcore mode.Field strip- you field strip the weaponDisassembly- you take the weapon completely apartAssembly- you put the firearm back togetherOperation- you fire the weapon, reload it and customize itGame- you disassemble the weapon and assemble the weapon as fast as you can (there are 3 achievements. Timed I is easy, Timed II is medium and Timed III is hard)Super game- Like game mode but harder. If you click on the wrong part you lose and you have to restart from scratch.Hardcore mode- you can make more moves. Example: when playing HC mode with an AK47 you can take the magazine, cleaning rod, top cover, pistol and the cleaning kit apart (located in the stock) in a few seconds. To unlock the hardcore achievement you must take your gun apart and assemble it flawlessly. You can not take things apart instantly. For example if you remove the magazine on some guns you can not remove another part while the magazine is being taken out. You have to wait for the animation to end in order to take another part apart or when putting parts back together.There are also shooting ranges where you shoot weapons and gain xp but you need xp to unlock them.In shooting ranges you are given a task to shoot X targets X ammount of times with X ammount of rounds.The reloading animations look robotic in my opinion but they are better than tacky animations.Its another game mode but if you want to unlock all of the guns then you might think about avoiding them but unlocking shooting ranges is also good because you can gain xp from them and possibly get credits from them on the first try (if your final score is good enough you might be the top scoring player of the day and receive 1 credit).And then there is Quiz. When playing Quiz you are given an image of a firearm and you have to pick the right answer.Sounds easy but if you are not familiar with alot of firearms you are gonna have a hard time because if you pick the wrong answer the quiz is over, you get 0xp and you have to wait 1 hour in order to take the quiz again.So the best way to play this is to memorize the models or print an image list. If you dont know the answer then the best option is to do nothing because something is better then nothing.There is also bonus content where you can take cars, motorcycles and skeletons apart. The human skeleton is free but the rest is not. Which brings me to xp and credits.The more guns you unlock the more xp you need to unlock the next model. Now you get a decent ammount of xp for playing the game modes but after unlocking the achievements you get less but depending on the model and the ammount of xp it requires you get more xp (a 16000xp model will give you more xp compared to a 10000xp model). Credits can be earned if you unlock the champion achievement (you can unlock it by topping the scorebored in the Day section. There is also Week and All time. Theres also highscores for each game mode. And if you lack the ability to think the Day section will show you the top scoring players of the day and yes the scoreboard resets). You also get free xp for playing the game the day after so the game is not that cruel. But if you lack patients you can buy a booster pack which doubles your xp or you can buy credits or xp with your money. 1.99 € for 5000 xp. You can also buy DLC to unlock everything but I have not looked that up very well so yeah you can simply buy all of the models for 50€.While that kinda sounds like a P2E (pay to enjoy) you can get all the models for free if you play casually.Casually playing is mini grinding and playing Quiz. When you have enough xp you unlock the model you want to unlock, have fun with it and start mini grinding and playing Quiz until you get the next one.Graphics- since my settings are set to low to get a lot of fps. I am not going to judge but it looks fine. Not super realistic but good for an educational game.Music and backround art- the music is fine but the backrounds are not. In my opinion the default backround is the best for me cus the space backrounds look cheesy. If you like the space backrounds go ahead and use em. What ever floats your boat keep it floating.Pros: educational, no major glitches, fun animations when taking the weapons apart, free and alot of models to check out.Cons: due to the ammount of xp you need you will grind at one point or another and it does take a while to unlock a new model.Tips: when taking firearms apart while trying to get the best time disable auto focus in the settings. Leave it on in disassembly and assembly mode for ease of learning.Overall the game is fine. Its not a mega fun blast. Its educational. 7.5/10

content:
9, 2014
												A fantastic Free 2 Play title that helps to gain insight in guns.The GUI is minimal, the models are really accurate and the textures are well made (except for some matte-black internal part).You can also operate the guns to see what happens when you pull the trigger (and whan you flip the selector/safety, when you remove the magazine and so on), thanks to the X-Ray view and to the cutoff view. You can also slow down the simulation up to 50 times.Disassembling and reassembling procedures are "simple" and clean thanks to the assonometric exploded view of the disassembled parts. "Simple" is between commas because you still have to learn and remember the disassembling order.There are hints (in case of you really can't see that tiny pivot holding up the entire safety lever), but don't rely on it too much if you want to achieve a good score.By completing tasks related to a model, you earn XP that you can spend to unlock further models. There's also a Quiz feature, where you get to recognize the gun by its silhouette.You can also try out some gun in shooting ranges, but I think they don't worth the cost.You can buy the sport cars pack or even the skeleton model pack. You can also buy the whole pack of models (98 models!!) for 36€, but hey, where's the challenge if you already unlock everyting by the start?If you know guns you'll like this game, and if you like this game you'll start to learn something about how a gun works.(Fun fact: I own a deactivated Desert Eagle .50AE, so I already knew how to disassemble it. Guess what, I got the best daily score with that gun. I already knew what to do, and the big work was only about clicking faster and faster.)

												This game. Oh, boy. Let's get started, shall we?PROS:-Gun disassembly is very accurate-Firing and executions are correct-Leaderboards to race against players-A true "story" experience (as long as you don't go along and use your mommy's credit card)-Large selection of weapons-Included disections such as a human skeleton, cars, etc.CONS:-Part(s) of the game require a substantial basis of money (which I'm not willing to pay)-Achievements of the guns give somewhat little EXP for their difficulties (I'm looking at you, Timed achievements. 400 EXP for my "perfection" of disassembling and assembling a Tec-9 in 1:37?)-Random selection of when to unlock guns in the game (the catalogue will allow you to get something at any time, with a little bit of extra pricing I believe). What I'm saying is, I would've started with pistols and you would've kept expanding into higher tiers of weapons: e.g. pistols, sub-machine guns, assault rifles, light-machine guns, sniper rifles, artillery.PERSONAL COMMENTS:-I know a very good general understanding of most weapons, and I love expanding my knowledge to more guns and learning how to fully disarm weapons.-I love field stripping weapons in real life, so this game really speaks to me.-I like looking inside the mechanics and seeing how a weapon works to a full extent.Hope any of my review helps your choice on downloading this or not, and if you're still not sure, it's a very quick DL and you can try it out for yourself.

												Solid unique concept with a few aching flaws.NEGATIVE:1)  Limited range use except for specific weapons.If you are going to spend all this time learning how to assembly/dissassembly/operate a firearm the next step is to range test.Not including this feature is a fundamental flaw.2)  No immediate action, misfire, or maintenance training included.3)  Some model assembly/ disassembly procedures are incorrect.4)  "Extreme grinding" to unlock advanced weapons.5)  Alternative models such as skeletons, cars, and motorcycles need to be dropped as they have no relevance.POSITIVE:1)  If you have the a lot of patience, memory, and time on your hands, the "puzzle" game is very good for learning weapon parts.2)  Good selection of current weapon models with more being added frequently.3)  Alternative ways to earn XP like quizes, inviting friends, coming back to play, and completing challengesIf the game adds ranges for all weapons or a general weapons range, and drops the full price or provides a bit more flexibility in pricing options than is currently offered (more than just buying ranges, , buying XP, or unlocking all weapons), a definate buy for gun enthusiasts.Otherwise, just log in once a day, get your free XP, and come back when you have enough to unlock another gun to play, or compete in a previous challenge to be No. 1 for an XP boost.

content:
y 30, 2015
												This is a very awesome and accurate 3d representation of guns and how they break down piece for piece. There are several modes of play from a basic field strip to a full on disassembly of the gun right down to the last screw and spring. There is a reassmebly mode and then there are 3 different game modes that require you to do a full disassemble and reassemble while being timed with bonuses for not clicking any of the wrong pieces among others. This game has a large and beautiful catalog of guns to choose from. Everything from Mauser to Glock as well as Beretta, Colt, AK variants, Heckler and Koch, Fabrique Nationale, Walther and many others.This is a fantastic game for any gun enthusiast. It will make you a lot more knowledgeable about the guns and how they break down. You can also see an x-ray view of how the gun works in real time or slow motion while it is in operation. If that isn't enough you can also fire guns off at firing ranges as you unlock them. (You must unlock guns as well as ranges) One downfall to this is that it doesn't let you choose which gun to use at the range. The ranges have 4 games which are preset to certain guns.In the end I don't think there is much to complain about. The game is free, and it has tons of guns. You can compete for high scores with other players and friends. You can learn about all of the parts of the guns, and you can even select an option that allows you to see the names of each and every part.If you love guns, get this game. You won't regret it. I own a beretta 92FS and I will say the break down of the gun in the game is 100% accurate to the real thing. Every spring, every pin, every screw. Perfect to a fault. Rating: 10/10

content:
er 19, 2014
												Gun Disassembly is basically an interactive encyclopedia about weapons, and not a bad one. There are a lot of weapons to read about, look at and disassemble to the smallest part, but not all of them are easily accessible. For instance, there are some guns, that cost a lot of xp points (36,000 for a simple pistol) and some require credits, which you can only get with real money. What saves this game from being a total grinder is weapons quiz. You have 30 seconds to recognise as many weapons as possible, and for 1 correct answer each, you get 300 xp points, which is a reasonable amount. There are some shooting areas, but I found those to be the weakest part of the game, boring and sluggish. If you are a Gun Nut, who's mostly interested in how weapons work, then I would strongly recommend this game, if not,  then you won't find much enjoyment here.

content:

Played for an hour, now I am become death.11/10Really more like a 7/10. It's a fun little toy for gun enthusiasts and hobbyists. So far, there seems to be a variety in the available guns, the accuracy of the firearms seems to be of top-notch quality, and the assembly and disassembly can be addicting. If you're looking for traditional fun, you will probably not find it as what you get in the game is what it advertises. You mostly assemble, disassemble, and learn about various firearms. If that doesn't interest, go elsewhere. There are two other gripes I have with the game. Firstly, if you lose connection to the servers, you're gonna have a bad time. It's not uncommon for me to lose connection which results in me having to restart the game. This is a nuisance and can become frustrating. The second major problem is the Facebook game-esque nature. You unlock things by grinding (assembling, disassembling, and playing games repeatedly) and inviting friends to play. You can also get things like XP boosts to unlock more guns and bonuses quicker. If you're not into having your fun held hostage until you get x amount of friends playing this, then go elsewhere.Personally, I love it so far.brb, assembling Kalashnikov

content:
10, 2015
TL;DRHave you ever wondered how firearms work? If so, this is a perfect opportunity to familiarise yourself with gun mechanics... for free!+ LOADS of firearms, including rifles, pistols, machine guns, grenade launchers, and even artillery+ Attention to detail+ X-ray, slow-motion, and other features help you see better how a gun works+ Quiz+ Low system requirements+ Suited both for short (although it may be hard to stop playing) and long sessions- Steals time like nobody's business- Inconsistent- Frustrating and unforgiving at times- GrindyREVIEWWorld of Guns: Gun Disassembly is a free gun puzzle game. It lets you disassemble and assemble firearms. Moreover, you can also see how a gun works and, albeit in a few cases only, visit a shooting range and put your aiming skills to test.The gameplay is centred around, you guessed it, assembling and disassembling weaponry. It relies mostly on memorising which parts to move and when to do that. You can move single parts and the whole assemblies. The downside associated with it is that the moveable parts vary from weapon to weapon and it is very easy to make mistakes when disassembling/assembling. Who said that gun assembly was easy?Apart from the clue of the game, you can also examine how a firearm works. There are some features which come in handy, including x-ray vision and slow-motion. During the "Operation", you perform many actions with the gun, such as fire, reload, attaching accessories (flashlights, scopes, etc.), changing the fire mode, and so on.The weaponry ranges from historical (Winchester 1887) to modern-day rifles (TAR-21) and everything in-between. There are well-over 100 guns, including pistols, machine guns, and even artillery. To access them, however, you have to earn it the hard way. You start with the AK-47 and unlock other weapons by spending either experience points or credits. The former are earned by completing the weapon tasks (field strip, disassembly, assembly, operation, normal game, super game, and hardcore game) and completing quizzes (one quiz per hour). The latter are either bought or earned by topping the scoreboard in normal, super, or hardcore games (one credit per weapon). Getting all the guns requires a lot of grinding, but that is to be expected from a free game.To sum up, I recommend this game not only to firearm fans but also to people playing casually. Despite being an unforgiving and sometimes frustrating game, it is still tons of fun to play and discover. Furthermore, it can be ran on pretty much any PC. Beware though: a wise man once said that this game should not be played at an airport. Mark his words, for you might miss your flight!P.S. Please check out my other reviews here: http://steamcommunity.com/id/FinnVArthur/recommended/My curation page: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/FVABot/curation

												Selling this as a "free to play" game is such a god damn lie its almost funny. This game is basically a demo of what could have been a great gunsmithing and learning game, but was plauged by those stupid, inevitable microtransactions. The saddest part is that its actually a really cool game if you are into guns and its an even better experience if you own a few yourself. That being the best part, i dont reccommend it unless you like to spend all of your money on microtransactions or if you have a good 10+ hours time to waste just to unlock ONE of the next guns (thats not an exxageration). The only thing that will not offer you a microtransaction is the uninstall button, which is really sad considering this game is such a good idea, just it was brought down by the developers greed. With the money spent earning every single gun, car, artillery cannon, in this game (there is a lot), you could go get yourself a good small caliber rifle to start learning off of in REAL LIFE. They really had a good idea to start off with and could have made this the best gunsmithing game to date, but they got money hungry and ruined such a nice game in the process. "Free to play" nowadays means "pay to win", its really sad. This game is a perfect example of that.

content:
, 2014
												Less a game, and more a simulation for people who want to dismantle and resemble firearms. Unlocking new firearms require a large number of points, meaning a user will be spending either a lot of time grinding activities repeatedly, or money on buying credits to unlock more weapons.While the simulation aspects might be accurate, ultimately, it's closer to image training program for anybody who really wants to disassemble firearms, than an actual game of any sort. In this sense, it belongs more in the software category than the game category.3/10

number of helpful: 22 of 42 people (52%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 18
												I would love it, I wish I could love this game, but I'm not here to grind, and the devs/pubs aren't here to not be money grubbing savages since this appears to be their only game on Steam. The level of savagery here is off the charts--foam at the mouth deception, painting the game as free to play, turning around and giving you all the traits of a pure pay to win game.>Ridiculous grind.>Microtransactions.>Free to play surface with DLC packages that *KILL* the point of the game.>Charging outragious prices and disregarding the point of the game.>You're either a degenerate with no life who uses unfunny public shooting incident memes living in their great grandparents' home, or you're a spoiled baby being schooled by this forty year old army veteran who doesn't know about these mouth-foaming, money devouring, soul-sucking fiends in the gaming market.Okay, sorry for that. Is this worth the value the developers/publishers are releasing it at? No. Period.What could they do to make this game actually worth it?-Less grind. *Much* less.-Remove most of the DLC packs, including the unlock-all one(NO EXCEPTIONS).-More subtle emphasis on competition(personal thing, competition's a bit intimidating, and not every gun nut is here to put together a gun the fastest in a ♥♥♥♥ measuring contest).-Of course, remove the microtransactions.-Work on VGUI(in general, pretty sure other people would want something better than this).What good is there besides these fiends trying to snatch up your wallet by the belly?+Pretty steep into details.+Not too hard, but there are challenges for you, and engaging events.+A leveling system so that you can't just go from putting a rock onto a stick all the way to performing surgery on a Centurion tank on the fly as a newbie--allthoughthegrindis♥♥♥♥ingawful.+Indepth analysis of model workings with simple, not too distracting x-ray effects, but slow-mo effects aren't quite on par, let alone the sounds in general.+Decent learning experience for a not so new gun nut who's already pretty into guns, but needs the extra kick.There's not much else to go about for me, and while the visuals aren't on par either, they don't really need to be. You're just being baby-stepped through the technical wonders of weaponry, not much is really needed visually, as this is a game for those interested, not more than the target audience.The major problem still cannot be avoided, you will probably have to pay real money if you sped through your first very few models already, and you may pay dearly.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
9, 2014
												So let me break it down. World of guns: Gun Disassembly is a unique 'game' if I've ever seen one.You start off with a classic Kalashnikova and work your way up to a colt, not much of a spoiler there. but yeah.The game is all about unlocking things; Field strip your gun to unlock dissasembly, dissasembly your gun to unlock reassembly... Assemble to operation, operation to game, game to super game and super game to hardcore game. You can geuss what the first three are; Operation is using the various features on a gun, changing handgrips, firing it, attaching a silencer or even folding a stock. The games however are a test to see your memory of how to put a gun together, you get bonus points and kudos if you manage to do it without touching the wrong part or taking a hint. On super game and up its instant failure to touch the wrong part and there is no hints.You might be thinking "okay thats easy" well... I've spent a bit of time getting raged at a gun for getting one peice wrong or forgetting what came first. A few times the game screws you over by saying "YOU NEED TO DO THIS FIRST" even though there are other points where you do the same thing and the game lets you.Example: You need to attach two rods to a plate and put the springs back on. One gun lets you put a rod and then the string on before having to deal with the second rod. But this particular gun needs both to be on.Its a bit annoying when some guns let you do it and doing it for real lets you do it.On the graphics end of it. The outside of the gun, looks awesome. 10/10 texturing. On the inside though... many parts have 'brush' texturing. This means that they are all are very basic tons of grey and black. Honestly they're just shaped blocks at that point, a mere representative. No complaint unless your obbscessed with HD textures.On the of the guns themselfves. TONS of variety. I find quite a few guns I like in their collection, however... I need to sift through alot of guns I don't cary about at all just to get to them. Sure you can buy the starter pack or the full unlock... but whats the fun of that? Well, i'll tell you: total access. Unless you got alot of time and patience, you won't get through this game without paying. Because the awarded points for working with a single gun almost never total enough to unlock a new one. Sure the points increase as you move on up... but the points needed per gun almost quadruple. So it makes playing fairly hard to do. Also you cannot earn any points through the ranges, I do not suggest unlocking them unless you really like the guns your using alot. Plus its just challenges and not free shooting; you also cannot repeat the challenges once you finish. The graphics for the range also take a plunk, going to CS 1.6 esque graphics. AKA Crappy world textures and okay gun textures.There is also another few ways to unlock points (two of them broken for me, reinstalling to see if it fixes it for me).First is coming back every day. Don't laugh you get a points bonus for coming back so many days in a row; even if you only pop in the grab that bonus. But make sure you come back every day or it'll reset.Next method is by joining the group and inviting freinds. I managed to join the group... but now it won't let me invite freinds because the button for it does not function. I have even used the other method in game and it still doesn't work. but this gives you some credits and a ton of XP to use on unlocking guns. But, I can't use it because it's broken.Last method is the quiz (which has a high failure rate for me... figures)Quizes test your ability to recognize the gun models, the more you get right is the more XP you get to walk away with. Get one wrong though and you lose your shot and get locked out for 2 hours.The funniest thing about the quiz not working for me is that it will go through just fine, but it will basically not give me the button to collect my points. It will however (even though I got all the questions right) lock me out for 2 hours. Its interesting to note that is registers me as unable to take another quiz... but yet I get none of my earned points. It only occasionally gives me my points for the quiz, if not... it basically locks the game up because it doesn't give me the button. CRAZIEST THING IS... If I fail the quiz, it doesn't crash at all. I feel like they're trying to keep me from getting points... Cheeki ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s.Anyways I'm reinstalling, still voting positive for this game. Even though its got a bunch of Cheeki Breeki coders.

												Interesting and possibly fun if you are curious or enthusiastic about the mechanics of real firearms. The XP grind is tolerable for those who want to perfect their knowledge. You'll get enough XP for the next firearm by the time you've mastered the current one. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												This game is essentially a facebook game, and it will probably only appeal to a select few. It's like a memory game with guns, with some sexy firing animations to break up the monotony. There is a lot of grinding, but most of it can be avoided by simply mastering the hourly quizes which will net roughly 1/3rd of the experience required for the best gun each time you take one. The best thing this game has going for it is the developers, who are probably some of the most active I've seen for any game. Just look at the Steam community forums, they respond to pretty much everything.I would love to see camera hotkeys similar to Starcraft where you set hotkeys to a predetermined camera state and more historical guns (let's face it most of the polymer pistols feel the same).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ry 13, 2015
												This is one of the most dangerous time sinks I have run into since Minecraft. I managed to unlock the Colt 1911, the MP5 and the Intratec Tec-9.  After a few hours turning them around seeing how everything works I went for the DLC with the unlimited guns. The M-16 A1 model brought back not-so-fond memories of skinning my knuckles trying to pull out the handguards. I also noticed that the o-rings in the bolt are stacked exactly like in real life, it's obvious that these models went through an insane amount of scrutiny. What's good:1. You get to see how most of everything inside works.2. You get to fire the weapons.What's not so good:1. The full weapons unlock should allow hiding all new guns and click to show/hide guns as needed so it is not so damn hard to navigate. It is overwhelming when you see all of the guns up to date displayed in one shot.2. I wish I could use my controller in the shooting games.3. The game doesn't explain things, it just walks you through. And sometimes the safeties can't be engaged by clicking on the weapon, you have to click a menu button.4. Sometimes the fire selectors don't allow all positions, so you are also stuck using a menu button to select fire modes.5. The only adjustable sight post that moves at all so far is the AK-47. The M16-A1s front post doesn't turn, unless I am doing something wrong. 6. Some weapons should allow movement of the hammer but the model only allows to pull back the slide. Wish list for the developers:1. Allow show/hide of items already purchased/unlocked/etc. 2. Allow a visualization of the return mechanism, for example the M16-A1 should show me the gas blow back, etc.3. Allow sights to move if/when the originals do. 4. Explain a little bit more of what's going on. 5. All safeties, fire selectors, de-cocking levers, etc. should be movable from the model, not from menu buttons. BTW, hats off to the parties responsible for the game mode achievement for doing things in the right order. It's frustrating as hell, but these being dangerous machines it makes sense to force people to learn an assembly sequence. I have been busting my ♥♥♥ for two long miserable days trying to do the Colt 1911 in order and I keep screwing up because I pick the main spring out of sequence or I click the recoil spring plug when I wanted to click on the recoil spring, that kind of thing. Overall:A complete absolute win for anyone that is curious about how machines work. The first time you dig into that AK-47 and you figure out on your own why the auto mode works, you'll feel like a rocket scientist.

11, 2016
												An in depth game showing how to disassemble, assemble, and operate many guns. There are fun options such as the x-ray view on a gun that allows you to see in depth (sort of) how the inside mechanics of a gun works. For free, if you play for a couple hours, you get full access to the ak-47, and a few pistols. However, this game will most likely feel incomplete if you don't pay real $ to unlock several of the expensive guns. Purchasing at least the $10 gun pack, which is what I did, gives you close to a complete experience of the game, so there's no need to buy the $50-60 "full game" option, unless you really, really like this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
, 2016
												A common complaint about videogame with firearms in them is the they aren't realistic enough.   This game changes that.  This is less of a video game and more of a gunsmith training aid.  Every firearm contained is a real life weapon.  The mechanics of how they work and how they come apart and go back together is accurate.  Ever wanted to see exactly how your favorite weapon in your favorite FPS actually works?  This "game" is your answer.  That being said, the GUI is a little clunky at times, and outside of getting achievements the first person aspects are not great.  None of this really really detracts from this little gem of a game.

												This is the perfect tool for anyone who is obsessed with weaponry. Firearms of all shapes and sizes are field stripped or fully stripped to your heart's content. The ability to cut away part of the weapon as you observe the firing mechanism and various attachments available for each individual weapon, with the option of multiple slow motion speeds and x-ray images, each highlighting different working parts, is mind blowing. You strip every last bolt and it is invaluable in teaching you how to safely strip and reassemble a wide variety of weapons and other objects, such as the Delorean, for a price. With the option to compete against other players around the world to see who can strip and reassemble the weapon in the fastest time, this game is awesome in every way. Specs and pics for each individual weapon is available, with links to websites for further information. I deem this game Worthy.

content:
3, 2014
												World of Guns: Gun Disassembly is a very good game for killing time, and learning about the guns and other things (Such as Skeletons and other goodies) that the game has to offer. While people complain about grinding, you can test your gun knowledge with a Quiz, that shows you images of guns by their silhouettes and asks you to identify the model. At a decent rate of 300 XP per correct answer, it's a good way to get experience.There are undoubtedly microtransactions in the game, though they're really quite unobtrusive. Credits, Experience, and other little packs can be bought to help the developers and get yourself a few new things as well. People in their reviews are complaining about the need to reassemble and disassemble the same gun to progress, however at this point in time I've not had to do that. The game itself offers login bonuses, in addition to the hourly test, that helps progression.Overall, it's an interesting little program that lets you assemble, disassemble, and operate weapons as slow or fast as you want to, with new weapon models being added every couple months. For a free game, it's really quite a bargain, as there's a way to get mostly everything without needing to buy so-and-so microtrasnaction. I enjoy it, and would recommend it to anyone who has a passion for guns.

content:
1, 2014
												I would like to make clear that I only got the free version of this game so my experience related within this review can only be based upon the free version and none of the paid versions of the game.Four words desricbe this game..."Gun tummy bannana rub" (I could do it in less words, but not here) 3.5 stars for the free version, the need to be super awesome or pay money to get more weps to strip is why I rate it down a bit ... Other than that I enjoyed my gun tummy bannana rub. Mainly because I have stripped and re-assembled various models of the AK-47 and M1911 and put them back together lots as a child. MODELS! not real ones!The ingenuity of the mechanisms in guns has always astonished me. This game shows all that engineering genius in the simplicity of the working parts in reasonably good detail, static and functioning. There is also a shooting range that is unlockable through experience earned or bought.One gripe from me, is that some pieces would not let me dissasemble them before I took apart another unrelated piece.There was no logical reason why I could not remove that part. This has happened in both the first two weapons and makes playing the super game mode more a "Learn what order your taught to do it" rather than " I got a screwdriver and there is a screw, I should be able to take it out now" You are then left with the looming fact that unless you learn those first 3 guns inside out and the correct order to do EVERYTHING you are going to have to pay money to get more guns.Oh, there is a "Bonus" part where you can dissasemble a human skeleton......... in a gun game ? What? ... well,  I done it anyway and put it back together again hoping to get enough experience to unlock something .. but no, it was not to be. 300XP didn't put a dent the 5000XP I needed for the next gun. There are other Skeletons...There are cars.As that last bit was totally confusing, we are just going to move on with the gun stuff.The question is , how much do you like guns? the first is an AK-47 and then a M1911. These weapons are a pleasure to strip and put back together (for me anyways) I do have a personal favourite that I am tempted to get,,, it looks like it will cost me a fiver though :( For me, I personally would really only get enjoyment out of weapons I am familair with.Last words are this,Try it, its actually educational and seeing the brutal simplicity of a death dealing tool in action is quite something.

content:

												This is a great game (even the comments are fun to read, especially Linkno1's). Personally, and this is probably just me... I think everyone should learn about guns, that way they wouldn't be such p*ssies when it came to owning and handling one. This game is a great first step in LEARNING about guns. Practice, of coarse, is a whole different story. My Wife and I both enjoy this game, because it's like a puzzle game combined with the game of Memory, combined with things that can kill and maim. What's not to like? And, for the record, my Wife didn't want guns in the house until I took her to the shooting range. Now she thinks she's Rambo. It's quite sexy (now, if I can just get her to wear a bikini when we go...). The only down-side is that when we argue, she swears she's gonna go "Tarantino on my ♥♥♥". I usually have to remind her that he often uses Mexican stand-off's in his films, which means that she wouldn't make it out alive either. Her response is "I don't care! I didn't bring you in this world... but I will take you out!" She's so cute.Anyway, If you want a chance at survival in dangerous situations this game is a good starting point in LEARNING about the tools you'll need (minus the tanks and rocket launchers... unless that's your thing... I'm not one to judge). If you want to be a scared victim, learn how to use the phone to call the cops, and die waiting for them. Although, I don't think there's a game for that... mainly because GUNS ARE COOL AND EVERYONE LOVES SHOOTING THINGS AND BLOWING THINGS UP! But I digress... if there is a game like that, it's probably British.AUTHOR'S NOTE: Before anyone gets upset at me for my last comment I just want to point out that shooting a home-invader in the face with a gun is a whole lot quicker than beating him/her about the head and shoulders with a cricket bat (although "ye ole willow wood" has less moving parts). Also, keep in mind that criminals don't care about gun laws. Come to think of it, they may not care about cricket rules either... I don't know... maybe try this game bundled with Don Bradman Cricket 14, or Counter-Strike: Global Offensive bundled with Cricket Revolution. Regardless, I recommend this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
8, 2014
												Not quite my definition of a "Game". More an educational simulator. It is a "Free-to-play" game in the sense that it comes with the nowadays standard (as much as it makes me want to stab someone with a rusty butterknife realising that) psychological warfare that is "microtransactions". For advance unlocks, "Credits", "Experience Boosters", etc.And the game is not without its problems:Some components you have to arbitrarily disassemble yourself, even when others do so automatically, which is an "inconsistency of the rules" I consider a crime.Additionally, some components that you'd assume could be removed or (dis)assembled without interference from other components (example, taking off a muzzle/compensator/suppressor thinking the front sight won't be a holdup), THINK AGAIN, you're doing it their way or not at all! Which is a rather irksome issue. Common sense says that such steps should be performable interchangeably. This is plainly evident with the AK-47's accessory case in the stock, were that step a requirement to proceed, I might think differently, but you can dissassemble everything BUT the stock without any restriction, not only implying that you already have tools on hand, but that the restriction has ZERO reason to be there! And that's from the *first* gun you work on.Each gun comes with its own array of "Achievements" you unlock towards a massive XP (which is used to unlock more guns) stipend at the end. However there are no less than two such achievements that rely on leaderboard placement. Which is equal parts skill, luck, and psychosis. (Guys, AXE THOSE ACHIEVEMENTS!)This issue is exasperated by the fact that some components take half-an-iceage to extricate or disassemble themselves.And lastly there is a small "quiz" minigame you can take every hour that tests your ability to identify certain firearms. Problems being that you only get the thumbnail from the gun "map" to go off of, so similar looking models are easily mistaken for eachother (I'm looking at YOU, Walther PP and Makarov PM!). And on top of that, when you get ONE wrong answer, all the experience you've built up (and it builds up quickly, which is nice, and sort of alleviates some of the aforementioned psych-warfare) is GONE. And the only way to get a question wrong and make off with the points is to let the 30 second timer run down.When you make a wrong answer, it tells you what the right answer was (after a short delay, which may confuse some), but when the timer runs out (whether by choice or simple lack of time), you leave with all accumulated points. Which may be interpreted as a tradeoff, you make a wrong response, you lose all points, but are told what the correct answer was, you let the timer run down, you keep all your points, but you are left in the dark on the last model. Which is especially frustrating when it (again) looks extremely similar to one or two other models. So, in short, make a judgement call: are you willing to lose all those points you've earned on a guess, or did you just start and have (almost) none to lose?Overall, I think this game can do a whole lot more in terms of educating (Example: What the hell is a sear? I've never heard of one until now!), it is nothing short of fascinating to see the internal workings of quality, classic, and iconic firearms. If you like guns, learning about them [not only do you get to (dis)assemble them, but each one has a comprehensive encyclopedia interface, complete with wiki links!], or are just curious about the internal workings of said guns, I give this game a (tentative) recommendation.

												If you like guns, or just like mechanical master-pieces, then this is the game for you. This game will teach you a indepth demonstration of: How to disassemble guns, how to reassemble guns, what all the gun part's names are and how the internals operate and function. There is a firing range for some of the firearms, and also a leaderboard system for if you have a competitive side or possibly just want to see what others have gotten for time wise. There is also a different section of other things such as: Bones, cars and AFVs. When I first tried this game I thought that since its free, it would be sh*t, but after only a few minutes of playing I found that it actualy is a very good simulator/teaching tool. This game has been very beneficial to me, in helping me understand everything about guns and all kinds of different guns, for when I fully enter my career and now have a huge leg-up. I also have now started designing and thinking about making proto-types of firearms of my own design. Overall I would strongly recommend this game, and will actively play this game for a long time to come.

content:
ry 15, 2015
												Very interesting game!It's free, so there's absolutely no reason for anybody to not try it - obviously, yeah, you can buy things in-game with real money, but it's not necessary unless you want to unlock more things/get more EXP faster (which, again - without paying a dime, you get a ton of content, so it's not necessary).If you're interested in guns at all, even just a little bit, then this game is for you.  The graphics, while not necessarily impressive, are nice, and the "Operation" mode is just outstanding.  Every working part of the gun is shown to you - be it in varying levels of X-ray mode, and/or in slow motion, you can see how a gun operates from the inside out.  This isn't just limited to one weapon, either - every gun you unlock, you can watch how all of the parts interact to fire a bullet.As well, the disassembly/assembly modes are pretty cool, and the "game" and "super game", and "hardcore game" modes are really fun.  You're not just racing the clock or grinding for EXP, you're learning how a gun is constructed at the same time.  I've field stripped a Colt 1911 in real life before, and this game has it down to a T.  I haven't fully disassembled one before, but I'm assuming they got that right, as well.All in all, really fun, sort of niche game that you should definitely go for.  It takes about 10 minutes to install, and is literally an educational time waster (for free!).

content:
ry 13, 2015
												This is one of the most dangerous time sinks I have run into since Minecraft. I managed to unlock the Colt 1911, the MP5 and the Intratec Tec-9.  After a few hours turning them around seeing how everything works I went for the DLC with the unlimited guns. The M-16 A1 model brought back not-so-fond memories of skinning my knuckles trying to pull out the handguards. I also noticed that the o-rings in the bolt are stacked exactly like in real life, it's obvious that these models went through an insane amount of scrutiny. What's good:1. You get to see how most of everything inside works.2. You get to fire the weapons.What's not so good:1. The full weapons unlock should allow hiding all new guns and click to show/hide guns as needed so it is not so damn hard to navigate. It is overwhelming when you see all of the guns up to date displayed in one shot.2. I wish I could use my controller in the shooting games.3. The game doesn't explain things, it just walks you through. And sometimes the safeties can't be engaged by clicking on the weapon, you have to click a menu button.4. Sometimes the fire selectors don't allow all positions, so you are also stuck using a menu button to select fire modes.5. The only adjustable sight post that moves at all so far is the AK-47. The M16-A1s front post doesn't turn, unless I am doing something wrong. 6. Some weapons should allow movement of the hammer but the model only allows to pull back the slide. Wish list for the developers:1. Allow show/hide of items already purchased/unlocked/etc. 2. Allow a visualization of the return mechanism, for example the M16-A1 should show me the gas blow back, etc.3. Allow sights to move if/when the originals do. 4. Explain a little bit more of what's going on. 5. All safeties, fire selectors, de-cocking levers, etc. should be movable from the model, not from menu buttons. BTW, hats off to the parties responsible for the game mode achievement for doing things in the right order. It's frustrating as hell, but these being dangerous machines it makes sense to force people to learn an assembly sequence. I have been busting my ♥♥♥ for two long miserable days trying to do the Colt 1911 in order and I keep screwing up because I pick the main spring out of sequence or I click the recoil spring plug when I wanted to click on the recoil spring, that kind of thing. Overall:A complete absolute win for anyone that is curious about how machines work. The first time you dig into that AK-47 and you figure out on your own why the auto mode works, you'll feel like a rocket scientist.

												This is a great game (even the comments are fun to read, especially Linkno1's). Personally, and this is probably just me... I think everyone should learn about guns, that way they wouldn't be such p*ssies when it came to owning and handling one. This game is a great first step in LEARNING about guns. Practice, of coarse, is a whole different story. My Wife and I both enjoy this game, because it's like a puzzle game combined with the game of Memory, combined with things that can kill and maim. What's not to like? And, for the record, my Wife didn't want guns in the house until I took her to the shooting range. Now she thinks she's Rambo. It's quite sexy (now, if I can just get her to wear a bikini when we go...). The only down-side is that when we argue, she swears she's gonna go "Tarantino on my ♥♥♥". I usually have to remind her that he often uses Mexican stand-off's in his films, which means that she wouldn't make it out alive either. Her response is "I don't care! I didn't bring you in this world... but I will take you out!" She's so cute.Anyway, If you want a chance at survival in dangerous situations this game is a good starting point in LEARNING about the tools you'll need (minus the tanks and rocket launchers... unless that's your thing... I'm not one to judge). If you want to be a scared victim, learn how to use the phone to call the cops, and die waiting for them. Although, I don't think there's a game for that... mainly because GUNS ARE COOL AND EVERYONE LOVES SHOOTING THINGS AND BLOWING THINGS UP! But I digress... if there is a game like that, it's probably British.AUTHOR'S NOTE: Before anyone gets upset at me for my last comment I just want to point out that shooting a home-invader in the face with a gun is a whole lot quicker than beating him/her about the head and shoulders with a cricket bat (although "ye ole willow wood" has less moving parts). Also, keep in mind that criminals don't care about gun laws. Come to think of it, they may not care about cricket rules either... I don't know... maybe try this game bundled with Don Bradman Cricket 14, or Counter-Strike: Global Offensive bundled with Cricket Revolution. Regardless, I recommend this game.

content:
0, 2014
												The game "World of Guns: Gun Disassembly" is exactly as it sounds. The whole game revolves around guns, but not only disassembling them, but also re-assembling them, checking and firing them, seeing how they work, shooting them on ranges, and you can also play 3 different types of assembly games. The first is basically to see how fast you can disassemble, then reassemble the gun. The second is the same, but there are no hints to whether or not the piece you select is one that can be removed at that moment, and if it turns out to be an immovable (unactivatable) piece (this is found out by clicking it twice, once to highlight, and twice to "activate" it, which is basically removing or re-adding it), you lose and you have to start ALL over again. The final one is like the first except you can move multiple pieces at once so you time can be even faster. The game can be pretty intruiging and educational about guns, but it's pretty repetative. By completeing achievements and games, you gain experience points which can be used to unlock ranges or new guns, and as you progress, the experience needed increases by the thousands meaning you have to repetatively disassemble and re-assemble guns, or play the games. Still, it's free to play, so I'd download it for the amusement factor. It's actually kinda educational.

content:
9, 2014
												So let me break it down. World of guns: Gun Disassembly is a unique 'game' if I've ever seen one.You start off with a classic Kalashnikova and work your way up to a colt, not much of a spoiler there. but yeah.The game is all about unlocking things; Field strip your gun to unlock dissasembly, dissasembly your gun to unlock reassembly... Assemble to operation, operation to game, game to super game and super game to hardcore game. You can geuss what the first three are; Operation is using the various features on a gun, changing handgrips, firing it, attaching a silencer or even folding a stock. The games however are a test to see your memory of how to put a gun together, you get bonus points and kudos if you manage to do it without touching the wrong part or taking a hint. On super game and up its instant failure to touch the wrong part and there is no hints.You might be thinking "okay thats easy" well... I've spent a bit of time getting raged at a gun for getting one peice wrong or forgetting what came first. A few times the game screws you over by saying "YOU NEED TO DO THIS FIRST" even though there are other points where you do the same thing and the game lets you.Example: You need to attach two rods to a plate and put the springs back on. One gun lets you put a rod and then the string on before having to deal with the second rod. But this particular gun needs both to be on.Its a bit annoying when some guns let you do it and doing it for real lets you do it.On the graphics end of it. The outside of the gun, looks awesome. 10/10 texturing. On the inside though... many parts have 'brush' texturing. This means that they are all are very basic tons of grey and black. Honestly they're just shaped blocks at that point, a mere representative. No complaint unless your obbscessed with HD textures.On the of the guns themselfves. TONS of variety. I find quite a few guns I like in their collection, however... I need to sift through alot of guns I don't cary about at all just to get to them. Sure you can buy the starter pack or the full unlock... but whats the fun of that? Well, i'll tell you: total access. Unless you got alot of time and patience, you won't get through this game without paying. Because the awarded points for working with a single gun almost never total enough to unlock a new one. Sure the points increase as you move on up... but the points needed per gun almost quadruple. So it makes playing fairly hard to do. Also you cannot earn any points through the ranges, I do not suggest unlocking them unless you really like the guns your using alot. Plus its just challenges and not free shooting; you also cannot repeat the challenges once you finish. The graphics for the range also take a plunk, going to CS 1.6 esque graphics. AKA Crappy world textures and okay gun textures.There is also another few ways to unlock points (two of them broken for me, reinstalling to see if it fixes it for me).First is coming back every day. Don't laugh you get a points bonus for coming back so many days in a row; even if you only pop in the grab that bonus. But make sure you come back every day or it'll reset.Next method is by joining the group and inviting freinds. I managed to join the group... but now it won't let me invite freinds because the button for it does not function. I have even used the other method in game and it still doesn't work. but this gives you some credits and a ton of XP to use on unlocking guns. But, I can't use it because it's broken.Last method is the quiz (which has a high failure rate for me... figures)Quizes test your ability to recognize the gun models, the more you get right is the more XP you get to walk away with. Get one wrong though and you lose your shot and get locked out for 2 hours.The funniest thing about the quiz not working for me is that it will go through just fine, but it will basically not give me the button to collect my points. It will however (even though I got all the questions right) lock me out for 2 hours. Its interesting to note that is registers me as unable to take another quiz... but yet I get none of my earned points. It only occasionally gives me my points for the quiz, if not... it basically locks the game up because it doesn't give me the button. CRAZIEST THING IS... If I fail the quiz, it doesn't crash at all. I feel like they're trying to keep me from getting points... Cheeki ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s.Anyways I'm reinstalling, still voting positive for this game. Even though its got a bunch of Cheeki Breeki coders.

												This is the perfect tool for anyone who is obsessed with weaponry. Firearms of all shapes and sizes are field stripped or fully stripped to your heart's content. The ability to cut away part of the weapon as you observe the firing mechanism and various attachments available for each individual weapon, with the option of multiple slow motion speeds and x-ray images, each highlighting different working parts, is mind blowing. content:
3, 2014
												World of Guns: Gun Disassembly is a very good game for killing time, and learning about the guns and other things (Such as Skeletons and other goodies) that the game has to offer. While people complain about grinding, you can test your gun knowledge with a Quiz, that shows you images of guns by their silhouettes and asks you to identify the model. At a decent rate of 300 XP per correct answer, it's a good way to get experience.There are undoubtedly microtransactions in the game, though they're really quite unobtrusive. Credits, Experience, and other little packs can be bought to help the developers and get yourself a few new things as well. People in their reviews are complaining about the need to reassemble and disassemble the same gun to progress, however at this point in time I've not had to do that. The game itself offers login bonuses, in addition to the hourly test, that helps progression.Overall, it's an interesting little program that lets you assemble, disassemble, and operate weapons as slow or fast as you want to, with new weapon models being added every couple months. For a free game, it's really quite a bargain, as there's a way to get mostly everything without needing to buy so-and-so microtrasnaction. I enjoy it, and would recommend it to anyone who has a passion for guns.

content:
er 13, 2014
												If you like guns this game is fun, addictive, and educational (and if you aren't trying to play for score, throw some music on, it's pretty relaxing). It's really interesting to see the differences and similarities between various designs from different ages and cultures--I have a newfound respect for Russian guns and a newfound hatred for German guns (why use two parts to do a job when you can use eighteen parts to do the same thing instead!), being able to trace design elements on the Desert Eagle back to the Jericho and then the CZ-75, how Ruger's copy of the Colt SAA is in many ways more complicated, etc. All of this is pretty interesting to me.But then again I'm a nerd about these things. I like the "operation" mode too, where you can see how the gun functions using varying levels of transparency and slow motion. It's all fantastically polished, especially being free to play.Not perfect though. As another reviewer mentioned, while the game requires you to remove and install parts in the proper order and shows animations of the various screws and pins, it leaves something to be desired as far as the actual method goes-- there's a difference between clicking on a 1911's recoil spring vs. slipping and sending the spring and plug across the room when you turn the barrel bushing, for example. So in its current form the educational aspects are limited, but I see a lot of potential there.All in all, though, it's a heck of a lotta fun.

												World of Guns is a free to play simulation that will appeal to two groups of people; those who already have knowledge of firearms and those who want to learn more about firearms. The game succeeds in making even something as dry as field stripping a firearm into a puzzle/memory game. The guns are finely detailed right down to individual screws that hold these mechanical marvels together. You start by field stripping a gun into its major components. As you progress you unlock further modes such as disassembly and assembly. Disassembly tasks you with taking down a given firearm into each of its individual parts. Assembly of course is putting it all back together. This then unlocks operation mode where you can then cycle between various levels of x-ray and cutaway views to see the gun in action. Its really quite something to see the internal mechanisms work. Finally there are game and super game modes. In game you simply try to disassemble and reassemble the firearm as fast as possible. In super game (hardcore) mode you have to meticulously disassemble and reassemble the firearm in the proper order otherwise you face failure and have to repeat it all over from the beginning. Of course this is repetitive but it is the kind of repetition that builds familiarity with that firearm. Its this cycle of repetition and learning that ultimately proves to be rewarding. However it can be frustrating in that you can fail in this mode for doing something in what the game perceives to be the wrong order yet would be still just fine if you were doing the same task in reality with the actual firearm.As you complete these game modes and various achievements you earn experience that can be used to unlock the next firearm. When the game first launched the prices were over priced. But looking through the shop now I think they have dropped prices on content considerably. This game has great potential to build upon with a new model promised every month. The game also allows you to disassemble and reassemble skeletons as well as vehicles.If you have a passion for firearms or want to learn more about how guns operate and how they have evolved; this game is certainly worth a look.

												When I first started playing this game, which I found by accident, I thought it was a bit too annoying for my taste, but once you start remembering all the parts for individual weapons, you feel some sort of accomplishment when you correctly complete a gun with 70+ parts without mistakes within a certain time.If you get this game, (It's free so why wouldn't you?), you will need to take into account that you cannot expect to complete this overnight (unless you pay £30 for the full unlocks). You could complete 3 or 4 weapons within the first day, but after that the exp costs of weapons starts to rise, and as repeating games nets you only 10% of the exp, you will have to count on gaining most exp through quiz's (every two hours) and daily rewards.Some bad things about this game would be you require 10 friends who play to unlock shooting ranges, invite 5 friends who don't play and get them to play the game for an achievement and exp. And that's really it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 13, 2014
												If you like guns this game is fun, addictive, and educational (and if you aren't trying to play for score, throw some music on, it's pretty relaxing). It's really interesting to see the differences and similarities between various designs from different ages and cultures--I have a newfound respect for Russian guns and a newfound hatred for German guns (why use two parts to do a job when you can use eighteen parts to do the same thing instead!), being able to trace design elements on the Desert Eagle back to the Jericho and then the CZ-75, how Ruger's copy of the Colt SAA is in many ways more complicated, etc. All of this is pretty interesting to me.But then again I'm a nerd about these things. I like the "operation" mode too, where you can see how the gun functions using varying levels of transparency and slow motion. It's all fantastically polished, especially being free to play.Not perfect though. As another reviewer mentioned, while the game requires you to remove and install parts in the proper order and shows animations of the various screws and pins, it leaves something to be desired as far as the actual method goes-- there's a difference between clicking on a 1911's recoil spring vs. slipping and sending the spring and plug across the room when you turn the barrel bushing, for example. So in its current form the educational aspects are limited, but I see a lot of potential there.All in all, though, it's a heck of a lotta fun.

content:
er 26, 2014
About The Game:Gun Disassembly isn't really a game, it's more of an interactive tool in which someone who is a "Firearms Enthusiast" (such as myself) or perhaps just has an interest in firearms can learn about different types of firearms, learn how they work, learn the ins and outs of each firearm, how to take them apart for maintenance etc. This tool is also avalible on mobile devices but it is certainly nice to have it avalible on the PC to enjoy in very high definition and also on a large screen.What's it About?:Well it's what it says on the Store Page it's all about Firearms if you're interested in learning how they work, what parts are inside the firearm or learn how to take apart and put them back together (perhaps for work, perhaps for cleaning or perhaps just because you're interested in learning about them.) then this is the tool for you!It allows you to learn all about firearms in a intereactive and very detailed game which allows you to take apart a firearm of your choice.The Verdict:Unlike any of my normal reviews there's not a great deal i can say about this as it's really not a game, there's no scores i can give for "graphics" or for "level design" etc this is just as it is a tool which allows the user to take apart firearms and learn how they work.If you're like me and are enthusiastic about Firearms and want to learn about how they work & operate then this is for you there's nothing more i can say, it's free and has a very large selection of firearms to choose from and learn with.Do i Recommend This?:Yes i do and i have no reason not to as it's free, if you're like me and love Firearms then this is something you should add to your Steam library.

All and all, highly recomend!  It's free, easy to use, and truly fun and addicting at times.

5, 2015
												Many gamers are running around and shooting with all kind of weapons. World of Guns: Gun Disassembly is all about real world weapons. It is not a violent game. Main part of the game is about disassembling and assembling your gun. There are a lot of different weapons, some with few and some with many parts, and about each month there is released a new one. You can play this free game the way you like. When you are only interested in how to dismantle your weapon, go ahead. Want to know how it works? Use slow motion and cutaway views. But you can also play on time and try to beat the daily number 1 or try to get a place in the top 100. It's all up the you. Disassembling and assembling and operating your weapon is giving you experience points, with which you can unlock new guns. When preferred you can buy the game (not a cheap game, but this week 50% off!), which unlocks all weapons at once. Or you can buy parts of the game like e.g. WW2 weapons. The free game takes longer to collect the needed points for unlocking a new weapon but there are no other restrictions. So why not give it a try! As for me, it's a fun game to play and I can really recommend it. For a free game I give it a 9 out of 10.

content:
5, 2014
												World of Guns reminds me a lot of World of Tanks in its ''ranking system''. And when I say that it reminds me of World of Tanks, I mean that I don't like it one bit.In this game you start off with the original ''bad guy gun'', also known as the Avtomat Kalashnikov 47 (AK-47). You have to learn step-by-step how to assemble and disassemble the gun very carefully and as fast as possible to unlock achievements and score the highest scores. However, to unlock a new weapon, you need to earn a lot of experience. For example, unlocking the gun after the AK-47, the Colt M1911, is a piece of cake because it only asks for 2000 experience points that you can easily unlock right after completing most of the challenges on the Kalashnikov, however, after the Colt, the experience cost dramatically rises to 5000 and then keeps getting higher and higher.With this massive experience cost, the game's grind rises dramatically which turns most of the players away from the game, seeking an easier alternative. The easiest alternative in the game, however, is to open your wallet and pay up. Yes, that's right, to unlock all of the guns, you can simply pay for DLCs. Pay-to-win, anyone?If you seek an enjoyable game in which you want to access all the sweet, juicy firearms and assemble/disassemble them all, test them and stuff, then this is not the game for you. Please wait for a better alternative.

												This a free to play puzzle / memory / edutainment game involving dissassembly and assembly of guns and shooting those guns.  You start with the AK-47 rifle, then you unlock Colt 1911 pistol quickly,  with 3,000 xp you can unlock HK MP5, might be a few more you can do for free.  The store sells DLC packs with a lot more guns, cars, motorcycles, skeletons, and xp buffs so it is Pay to Progress.  If you get five friends on Steam to play game, you can earn 20,000 xp and 20 credits.  There is shooting ranges you can unlock for firing those guns, i guess there is games and achievements you can do at each shooting range.  There is a leaderboard for your times and scores versus other players.  There is games involving dissassembly and assembly of guns.  You can operate those guns while using modes: x-ray, cutaway, slow motion, rotating. Has Steam achievements, few which are easy to obtain, many requiring paying real money.The camera movement is clunky and can get in the way on timed dissassembly and assembly of guns.Try it, you might learn something. Great for those gun toting NRA members.for more info:

content:
2, 2015
												World of Guns is a great game if you just want to kill a couple of minutes at a time, but it can still hold up extended sessions too. It's very interesting to see the workings of all the models without having to own them and get a reputation as a murderous lunatic. That, and actually since you can hide parts and slow down time while watching the weapons operate, it gives some insights into the gun that most people wouldn't be able to uncover with equipment they have at home even if they owned it.The biggest problem for me is that the game is ever so slightly skittish on the virtual currency and clearly tries to goad the player into forking out some cash. This would be no problem otherwise, but I don't want to buy the exp straight out as it's the pacing that keeps the game interesting, nor do I want to unlock weapons directly, for the same reason. The boosters are cheaply done; they only last an hour and are much too expensive. The only real incentive to spend money I see here is stickers and other cosmetics for the guns, which I'm not all that interested in. In fact I find the ability to customize the guns with bright colors, animal prints and stick-on pictures a bit tacky.Something I could see myself pay for would be a premium version where I can take apart all the weapon accessories I normally only get to see attached in operation mode. The differences between skeleton, wooden and synthetic stocks could be interesting, for example. Or maybe being able to operate weapons with parts taken off (and getting to see malfunctions, dry fire, etc). For the right price I could pay for these features even gun by gun.

												This game's hard to recommend to everyone, so I won't. Can't beat that deal.It's great fun if you're super weird and like taking stuff apart; that's pretty much it. Just try it. It's 90 MBs and free. If you don't like it, you can try it and be done in like 15 minutes.

content:
y 7, 2016
												Quick Evaluation===========================The Game itself has many pro's and few con's, yet the con's make it obnoxious at times.Pro's-+MANY Weapons to model and even re-texture yourself+Support for other languages, this is actually often forgotten+Supports direct workshop addition, as well as Modded weapon models+Accurate models *to my knowledge*+Customizable backgrounds and mute option for music to add [s]dank meme songs[/s] good music while working.Con's--TOO MANY MICROTRANSACTION SECTIONS-Micro-Transactions lock out certain features that would have been nice to do, as well as easier to buy models etc.-Confusing Menu screens-Misleading titles on certain things================================="In-Depth" Review-This game first sparked my interest after seeing the youtuber WarOwl play it, and at that moment, with my fascination of weapons, went and downloaded it, it being free is the coolest non-game-feature. The install itself takes less than 5 minutes, even on wifi from a far away connection zone (tested this for a friend). The game immediately starts up and changing the [s]ridiculous[/s] music to mute was a great feature, as well as changing the background for the screen when dissassembling weapons and such. The tutorial wasn't as great as I'd hoped it would be, but it definitely sufficed enough to let me learn on my own, at my own pace, and even gave me a "free" model as part of showing me how to buy them. After the initial tutorial though, there isn't much help finding out how to do in-depth things such as duplicating stickers on your guns, or other things that without needing to do it, seems pointless to even make a help document or tutorial for, so I get it. The overall quality of the game surprised me, and the x-ray feature allows you to see the insides of mechanics that when firing normally aren't visible, and the accuracy of the models are as accurate as any I've seen or field stripped myself at gun shops, etc. Overall this game is a fun time consumer, that can teach you more about guns, or even designing, if you want to texture guns for CS:GO etc. I really do reccomend this since its free, so what's the harm, and its fun to mess around in!

content:
r 12, 2015
												When I first purchased this game, I was thinking this was going to be some kind ofmemory game... And well, it is... but it's so much more...First off, this is a memory game, but not just any memory game. It's a game about disassembling, reassembling, and even remembering how each gun is taken apart and put back together with & without using the guides. This game is really about remembering the order in which you have to assemble the parts. There's also a shooting range for each gun so you get an idea on how to use the gun as well as teaches you how to spare your ammo for each target and on how you can learn to use each gun on aiming, handle and even practice on moving targets.One thing to note about this game is that, although it is called "World Of Guns", it's not just about guns. There's also sections of the game that lets you disassemble and reassemble skeletons, army vehicles (Tank & humvee), sports cars, and even a harley.During the course of playing the game, you also get some really neat info about each weapon, vehicle, and skeleton. Details about the make, model, history, concept, and what went into making each weapon.What I like most about this game is how well detailed the designer put into making each part of every weapon. Someone did some serious homework on this game based on how many parts each gun has. I found this game not only fun, but also informative, and even help me to learn to respect weapons. Learning how the mechanics and insides work was the best part about his game.I have read some other reviews and they seem to claim that some parts of the game were too hard. Although I can somewhat understand, this is more of a memory game as each gun, vehicle, skeleton as an order in which it's assembled, so you have to remember the order of the parts in order to get a good score. This is a memory game, not so much a shooter game. Some guns have as much as 100+ parts to remember, while a few guns only have say 20-30 parts. Every part has it's place, every part must also be done in a certain order, so you got to use your head more than use your speed. Once you know how the parts go, speed will follow. This is is a trial and error game as well as memory game. If you like memory games, this is a good game to get.WARNING = Although this game is free, you can purchase download content which opens up ALL the areas of the game or you can purchase experience points as well as credits to open up only a few select areas. You only start out with 1 gun at the beginning and must earn experience and credits to open up other areas of the game. you earn experience and credits when you complete tasks on each gun.

content:
y 10, 2015
												Pros: Extremely detailed. Very relaxing. The actual process is exhaustively accurate (or at least aspires to be - I don't own a gun myself that I can cross-check their work with.) If a given part could not be removed in reality without removing another part, the game makes you do it in the correct order. It also forces you to deal with parts so small that they don't initially seem to be there even on a close examination. "Plastic" mode colors all the parts differently in bright neon colors to make them stand out more, useful in these cases. A competitive element that you can engage or ignore freely - each gun has leaderboards you can compare yourself against. There's also cars and skeletons to disassemble, although only a handful of each, and a motorcycle and two military vehicles. The game includes shooting ranges and challenges to allow you to play with the guns as well as just examine them, but it appears that not all guns have corresponding ranges. Out of the five I've unlocked, only two have such levels.Cons: You start with only three models - AK-47. 1911, and a human skeleton (under bonus models.) To unlock more guns, you have to either save up experience points or spend real-world money. If you're willing to spend money, you unlock guns quite quickly. To do it through XP, you have to grind. That's slow - I'm seven hours in, and have unlocked just three additional guns. (Keep in mind that each gun I have encountered so far takes no more than ten minutes to completely disassemble and re-assemble - and that's the first time attacking a relatively complex gun like the AK. The TEC-9, clocking in at less than forty parts, took just five minutes total, and judging by the leaderboards, I'm slow.) What's more, guns unlock in a specific order along a tree like a Civ V tech tree, except that it goes in multiple directions. You have to unlock eight guns to get to the Garand, for instance, and those eight guns take you in the opposite direction from the Desert Eagle, for another example. You cannot actually see the whole tree to begin with, either. You see the next guns available to unlock, and you can see vague outlines of the ones after that with no names or detail. After that, nothing. You have to consult charts made by other players to plan your unlocks more than two steps ahead. There's also a handful of guns that can be unlocked only with purchased credits. There are often  guns beyond these that can only be accessed by getting through that one gun - so while they're "free," you can't get at them without having paid. Virtually all of the respectable handful of non-gun models are paid-credits only, as well.Conclusion: It's good for killing a few hours here or there, but completionists should be aware that it is impossible to 100 percent this title without paying, and everyone should be aware that what progress you can make is made only at a comparative crawl.

												If I could rate t neutral believe me I would. I like it because it is a great time killer but this game should just be free. No dlcs. No unlockables. Just free to play. I say this because it is just a game of disassembling and reassembling various guns with an optional challenge mode. The dlc matter is tricky because I can get over 100 guns and counting but the problem is that the season pass dlc is the same price as a newly released AAA title game which honestly is pretty damn outrageous even though I might purchase it. The point system is dull and take forever. Taking apart and rebuilding a gun totals to sixty points which is way too low and gets boring easily considering most guns are 15,000 points. It's like a digital arcade center: you play games and earn tokens, tickets but after a couple hours you still don't have enough for the cool lava lamp or in this case a pistol. All in All it's good but needs to be 100% free.

												One of the best Free-to-play games on Steam! Very entertaining, yet very competitive if the player wants some challenges. Not quite a full arsenal of both historical and modern weapons, but there are many platforms, and the field strip/disassemble/reassemble processes are accurate. In general, this game will keep the player busy for some time. Definitely recommended.
